title: In Letter, Trump Urged Erdogan to Make a Deal
text:
WASHINGTON—President Trump urged his Turkish counterpart in a letter last week to “make a great deal” with Kurdish fighters following the launch of Turkey’s military offensive in Syria, warning him: “Don’t be a fool.”

White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham confirmed the authenticity of the letter, which was earlier posted on Twitter by a Fox Business Network reporter. The brief letter, written in a highly colloquial style, was sent to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Oct. 9, days after Mr. Trump ordered the withdrawal of U.S. forces in the area, clearing the way for the long-threatened incursion by Turkey.

At the time, Mr. Trump had already drawn staunch bipartisan condemnation from lawmakers, who said the U.S. withdrawal meant abandoning U.S.-allied Kurdish fighters in northeastern Syria. Mr. Trump has argued that he doesn’t want U.S. troops to be in the middle of a longstanding feud between Turkey and Kurdish fighters, but also threatened debilitating sanctions against Ankara.

Read the Full Letter to Erdogan VIEW Document A copy of the letter dated Oct. 9. 2019, sent from President Donald Trump to Turkey's President, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

“You don’t want to be responsible for slaughtering thousands of people, and I don’t want to be responsible for destroying the Turkish economy—and I will,” the letter begins. He also reminded Mr. Erdogan of now-lifted sanctions tied to the detention of American Andrew Brunson, warning: “I’ve already given you a little sample with respect to Pastor Brunson.” He adds: “Don’t let the world down. You can make a great deal.”

In the letter, he says that Kurdish commander Mazloum Abdi is willing to negotiate and to make concessions to end the violence.

“History will look upon you favorably if you get this done the right and humane way,” he concludes. “It will look upon you forever as the devil if good things don’t happen. Don’t be a tough guy. Don’t be a fool.”

Mr. Erdogan first informed Mr. Trump in an Oct. 6 phone call that he intended to go ahead with his long-threatened plans to launch a cross-border military operation in northeastern Syria. Mr. Trump immediately announced that he would withdraw U.S. forces from the area, releasing a statement late Sunday night.

Mr. Trump has dispatched Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Vice President Mike Pence to Ankara to urge Mr. Erdogan to stop the weeklong military incursion. Mr. Trump disclosed the existence of the letter earlier Wednesday in remarks to reporters at the White House.

In comments from the Oval Office, President Trump stood by his decision to withdraw U.S. troops from the Syrian border, and said it was up to other countries to fight ISIS now. Photo: Michael Reynolds/Shutterstock
